data.title: Golden State Warriors: 25 Best Players To Play For The Warriors
data.meta_description: The Golden State Warriors are one of three franchise remaining from the founding of the Basketball Association of America in 1946, Who are their 25 best?The Golden State Warriors are one of three active NBA teams that trace its lineage to the founding of the Basketball Association of America i...
data.text:
The Golden State Warriors are one of three franchise remaining from the founding of the Basketball Association of America in 1946, Who are their 25 best?

June 2, 2016; Oakland, CA, USA; General exterior view before the Golden State Warriors play against the Cleveland Cavaliers in game one of the NBA Finals at Oracle Arena. Mandatory Credit: Bob Donnan-USA TODAY Sports

The Golden State Warriors are one of three active NBA teams that trace its lineage to the founding of the Basketball Association of America in 1946, but unlike the Boston Celtics and New York Knicks, the Warriors didn’t remain in their original location.

The Philadelphia Warriors were begun by minor-league hockey club owner Peter Tyrrell and the franchise spent its first 16 seasons in the City of Brotherly Love, playing its home games at the Philadelphia Arena throughout its stay, while also playing in the newer Philadelphia Convention Center at times from 1952-62.

Eddie Gottlieb, the team’s first coach and general manager, purchased the team from Tyrrell in 1952 until he sold it to a group of Bay Area investors led by Franklin Mieuli, who moved the team to San Francisco in 1962.

The San Francisco Warriors played … just about everywhere.

They were at the Cow Palace for their first two seasons, spent two seasons playing at both the San Francisco Civic Auditorium (now known as the Bill Graham Civic Auditorium) and Memorial Gym on the campus of the University of San Francisco before returning to the Cow Palace in 1966.

In 1971, the Warriors moved across the bay to the Oakland Coliseum Arena (now known as Oracle Arena) and were renamed the Golden State Warriors.

That’s been their home since, except for the 1996-97 season, when they played at the San Jose Arena while Oakland Coliseum Arena was being renovated and rechristened The Arena in Oakland.

The Warriors have won four titles, two each in Philadelphia and Golden State. The Warriors won the initial BAA championship in 1947, defeating the Chicago Stags in six games and took down the Fort Wayne Pistons in five games to win the NBA title in 1956.

Golden State swept the favored Washington Bullets to capture the championship in 1975, but it would be a 40-year wait to get back to the Finals. The Warriors topped the Cleveland Cavaliers in six games to win the 2015 NBA title.

Philadelphia lost in the Finals to the Baltimore Bullets in 1948, while the San Francisco version of the Warriors lost to the Celtics in 1964 and to the Philadelphia 76ers in 1967.

In 2015-16, however, the Golden State edition of the Warriors learned that history is a fickle mistress.

After going 68 seasons without a 60-win season, Golden State upped the ante last season with an NBA-record 73-9 regular season.

But as Laurence Fishburne’s Morpheus told Keanu Reeves’ Neo in The Matrix, “Fate, it seems, is not without a sense of irony.”

This record-setting unit ended its season making the wrong kind of history, becoming the first team in NBA Finals history to lose after taking a 3-1 lead.

The franchise is 2,590-2,884 in its 70 seasons, with its .473 winning percentage ranking 20th among the 30 active teams in the NBA.

The club has made 32 playoff appearances in 70 years and has topped the 60-win plateau twice–the last two seasons.

There have been seven 60-loss seasons, but the worst winning percentage came in 1952-53, when Philadelphia finished 12-57 (.174).

The record for most losses in a season came in 2000-01 when the Warriors were 17-65. The team was 17-63 in 1964-65, 19-63 in 1997-98 and 1999-2000, 20-62 in 1987-88, 21-61 in 2001-02 and 22-60 in 1984-85.

The six consecutive playoff appearances the Warriors had in Philadelphia at the start of the franchise remains the longest such streak in team history.

But Golden State had a stretch of 12 straight seasons, 1994-95 through 2005-06, without seeing the postseason.

Gottlieb served the longest as general manager, from the franchise’s inception in 1946 to August 1963. Bob Feerick had the position from August 1963 to June 1974, Al Attles was GM from June 1976 to May 1986 and Don Nelson served from December 1987 to February 1995.

Current GM Bob Myers has been in his post since April 2012.

The Warriors have had two Executive of the Year winners, Dick Vertlieb in 1974-75 and Myers in 2014-15.

Attles is the franchise’s winningest coach, going 557-518 in the regular season and 31-30 in the playoffs from 1970-83. Nelson was 422-443 and 14-21 in two stints, 1988-95 and 2006-10. Gottlieb went 263-318 and 15-17 from 1946-55.

Current coach Steve Kerr was hired in May 2014 and is 140-24 in the regular season and 31-14 in the postseason, becoming the third Warrior coach to be named Coach of the Year in 2015-16.

Alex Hannum was named in 1963-64 and Nelson won the honor in 1991-92.

The Warriors have had the No. 1 pick three times in their history, once in the lottery era.

In 1965, San Francisco selected Davidson’s Fred Hetzel. In 1980, Golden State went with Joe Barry Carroll from Purdue and in 1995, Maryland’s Joe Smith was the top pick.

They have picked second once, third six times and fifth six times. The Warriors have never had the No. 4 overall selection.

Here are the 25 best players in the history of the Philadelphia/San Francisco/Golden State Warriors. Players had to have appeared in 150 games and averaged a minimum of 20 minutes per game for the team to qualify for this list.

1988: Eric Sleepy Floyd #21 of the Golden State Warriors drives upcourt during an NBA game in the 1988-89 season. (Photo by: Otto Greule Jr/Getty Images

Sleepy Floyd

PG-SG, 1983-87

The Golden State Warriors landed a rookie guard with promise in February 1983, picking up Sleepy Floyd along with Mickey Johnson from the New Jersey Nets in exchange for Micheal Ray Richardson.

Floyd went on to be named an All-Star in 1987 for the Warriors, during a 1986-87 campaign during which he was second in the NBA in assists.

In December 1987, Floyd was traded with Joe Barry Carroll and cash to the Houston Rockets in exchange for Ralph Sampson and Steve Harris.

In parts of six seasons in Golden State, Floyd averaged 17.7 points, 6.7 assists, 3.3 rebounds and 1.6 steals in 33.9 minutes per game, shooting .468/.320/.824.

A two-time All-American at Georgetown, Floyd averaged 16.7 points per game as a senior while leading the Hoyas to the national championship game.

He was the 13th overall pick by the Nets in the 1982 NBA Draft.

Waived by Houston in August 1993, he signed with the San Antonio Spurs in October of that year.

Floyd returned to the Nets as a free agent in October 1994, retiring after the 1994-95 season.

SEATTLE – 1970: Tom Meschery #14 of the San Francisco Warriors shoots a jumper during a game played in 1970 in Seattle, Washington. Copyright 1970 NBAE (Photo by NBA Photos/NBAE via Getty Images)

Tom, Meschery

PF-SF, 1961-67

Tom Meschery closed out his collegiate career at Saint Mary’s averaging 20.8 points and 13.0 rebounds per game as a senior and put himself in the mix as a top professional prospect.

The Philadelphia Warriors selected Meschery with the seventh overall pick in the 1961 NBA Draft and plugged him into the power forward spot next to Wilt Chamberlain as a rookie.

In 1962, the Warriors moved to San Francisco, creating a homecoming for Meschery, who had played at Lowell High School in the city.

Meschery was an All-Star in 1963. Moved to small forward the following season and returned to the 4 spot in 1965-66, Meschery remained with the Warriors until he was left exposed to the expansion draft in May 1967.

Selected by the Seattle SuperSonics, Meschery finished his career in the Northwest.

In six seasons in Philadelphia and San Francisco, Meschery averaged 12.9 points and 8.5 rebounds in 30.4 minutes per game, shooting 42.4 percent from the floor and 74.7 percent at the line. He does not appear on any of the franchise’s all-time leaderboards.

He spent four years with the Sonics before retiring after the 1970-71 season.

In September 1971, Meschery was hired to coach the ABA’s Carolina Cougars. He spent one season in that post, going 35-49 and missing the playoffs before resigning in April 1972.

A renowned poet in retirement, Meschery taught high school English in Reno, Nev., until retiring in 2005, and his son, Matthew Meschery, is a former lead vocalist for the band OPM.

NEW YORK, NY – APRIL 17: Retired basketball player Cazzie Russell attends the Tribeca/ESPN Sports Film Festival Gala: ‘When The Garden Was Eden’ during the 2014 Tribeca Film Festival at BMCC Tribeca PAC on April 17, 2014 in New York City. (Photo by Ben Gabbe/Getty Images for the 2014 Tribeca Film Festival )

Cazzie Russell

SF, 1971-74

The San Francisco Warriors were on the verge of jumping across the Bay to Oakland when they acquired Cazzie Russell from the New York Knicks in May 1971 in exchange for Jerry Lucas.

Russell came to the Warriors and was an All-Star in 1972 and was a solid performer before leaving to sign with the Los Angeles Lakers in September 1974 as a veteran free agent.

The Warriors acquired a first-round pick in 1976 as compensation.

In three seasons in Golden State, Russell averaged 19.2 points, 4.7 rebounds and 2.6 assists in 32.8 minutes per game, shooting 46.6 percent from the floor and 84.1 percent at the line.

He was a three-time All-American at Michigan, averaging 30.8 points and 8.4 rebounds per game as a senior.

Russell was the first overall pick by the Knicks in the 1966 NBA Draft and was an All-Rookie selection in 1966-67. He was also part of their NBA championship club in 1970.

He was third in the league in free-throw shooting for Los Angeles in 1975-76.

Russell was waived by Los Angeles in October 1977 and signed with the Chicago Bulls in January 1978.

Unsigned after the 1977-78 season, Russell played the 1978-79 season in the Western Basketball Association and in 1980-81 in the Eastern Basketball Association before retiring.

Basketball: Golden St. Warriors Latrell Sprewell #15 in action vs Utah Jazz. (Photo by Sam Forencich/The LIFE Images Collection/Getty Images)

Latrell Sprewell

SG, 1992-97

Latrell Sprewell was a late bloomer at Alabama, averaging almost 18 points and more than five rebounds per game as a senior and was taken by the Golden State Warriors with the 24th overall pick of the 1992 NBA Draft.

He was a revelation in the late first round, earning All-Rookie honors in 1992-93 and going on to be named a three-time All-Star with the Warriors. Sprewell was also named both All-NBA and All-Defensive in 1993-94.

He was fourth in the NBA in three-pointers and led the league in minutes per game in 1993-94. He was third in minutes per game in 1994-95 and 1996-97, as well.

But his time with the Warriors came to an infamous and ignominious end when he was waived and suspended by the NBA for a year after choking coach P.J. Carlesimo during a Dec. 1, 1997, practice.

An arbitrator later reinstated his contract and reduced the suspension to the remainder of the 1997-98 season, but his time with the Warriors was done.

In January 1999, he was traded to the New York Knicks in exchange for John Starks, Chris Mills and Terry Cummings.

In parts of six seasons in Golden State, Sprewell averaged 20.1 points, 4.7 assists, 4.3 rebounds and 1.7 steals in 40.0 minutes per game, shooting .436/.332/.791.

An All-Star in 2001 with the Knicks, he also helped New York to the NBA Finals in 1999.

Sprewell was traded to the Minnesota Timberwolves in July 2003 as part of a four-team deal and wound up retiring after going unsigned as a free agent in the summer of 2005.

He is 10th in NBA history with an average of 38.6 minutes per game.

Basketball: Golden State Warriors Bernard King (30) in action, jump ball vs New Jersey Nets Mike O’Koren (31) at Oakland-Alameda County Coliseum Arena.

Oakland, CA 12/3/1980

CREDIT: Andy Hayt (Photo by Andy Hayt /Sports Illustrated/Getty Images)

(Set Number: X25132 )

Bernard King

SF, 1980-82

Bernard King had endured a turbulent season with the Utah Jazz, punctuated by a half-season suspension following his arrest in January 1980 on five felony charges, pleading guilty to lesser counts.

The Golden State Warriors took a chance on the talented but troubled small forward, acquiring him from the Jazz in September 1980 in exchange for Wayne Cooper and a second-round pick in 1981.

King was an All-Star in 1982 for the Warriors and an All-NBA selection in 1981-82. He was fourth in the NBA in field-goal percentage in 1980-81.

In October 1982, King was traded to the New York Knicks in exchange for Micheal Ray Richardson and a fifth-round pick in 1984.

In two seasons in Golden State, King averaged 22.5 points, 6.4 rebounds and 3.6 assists in 36.1 minutes per game, shooting .577/3-for-11/.704.

King was a two-time All-American at Tennessee and averaged 25.8 points and 14.3 rebounds per game as a junior before entering the draft.

King was the seventh overall pick by the New Jersey Nets in the 1977 NBA Draft and was an All-Rookie selection in 1977-78 before being traded to the Jazz In October 1979.

With the Knicks, King was a two-time All-Star and two-time All-NBA selection, leading the NBA in scoring in 1984-85.

In October 1987, he signed as a free agent with the Washington Bullets, earning an All-Star bid in 1991 and All-NBA recognition in 1990-91.

Waived in January 1993, King signed with New Jersey the following month, retiring at the end of the 1992-93 campaign.

Inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame in 2013, he is 43rd in NBA history with 19,655 points and 24th with an average of 22.5 points per game.

1989-1990: Guard Mitch Richmond of the Golden State Warriors in action with the basketball.

Mitch Richmond

SG, 1988-91

Mitch Richmond scored almost at will as a senior at Kansas State, averaging almost 23 points and more than six rebounds per game.

The Golden State Warriors took the shooting guard with the fifth overall pick in the 1988 NBA Draft.

He was legit, earning Rookie of the Year honors in 1988-89. Richmond was also third in the NBA in minutes per game in 1990-91.

But in November 1991, Richmond was traded with Les Jepsen and a second-round pick in 1995 to the Sacramento Kings in exchange for the rights to third overall pick Billy Owens in one of the worst trades in team history.

In three seasons in Golden State, Richmond averaged 22.7 points, 5.5 rebounds, 3.4 assists and 1.3 steals in 36.5 minutes per game, shooting .486/.357/.840.

Richmond was a six-time All-Star with the Kings, earning All-NBA honors five times. He also placed fourth in the league in three-pointers twice for Sacramento.

He was traded to the Washington Wizards in May 1998.

In July 2001, he signed with the Los Angeles Lakers, retiring after earning a championship ring in 2002.

Inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame in 2014, Richmond is 33rd in NBA history with 1,326 three-pointers and 38th with 20,497 points and an average of 21.0 points per game.

Jun 19, 2016; Oakland, CA, USA; Golden State Warriors forward Andre Iguodala (9) handles the ball against Cleveland Cavaliers center Tristan Thompson (13) during the first quarter in game seven of the NBA Finals at Oracle Arena. Mandatory Credit: Bob Donnan-USA TODAY Sports

Andre Iguodala

SF, 2013-16

Andre Iguodala was one of the premier free agents on the market after the 2012-13 season and it was the Golden State Warriors who landed him.

After agreeing with the tenacious wing defender on a four-year, $48 million deal in July 2013, the Warriors acquired him via a sign-and-trade deal from the Denver Nuggets, also acquiring Kevin Murphy from the Utah Jazz.

Golden State sent a 2018 second-round pick to the Nuggets while dispatching Brandon Rush, Richard Jefferson and Andris Biedrins along with first-round picks in 2014 and 2017 and second-rounders in 2016 and 2017 to Utah.

Iguodala was an All-Defensive selection in 2013-14 for the Warriors.

But the arrival of coach Steve Kerr in 2014 sent Iguodala’s career in a new direction as a sixth man.

As Golden State won its first championship in 40 years in 2015, Iguodala stole the show in the NBA Finals, becoming the first non-starter to earn Finals MVP honors.

He did start three of the six games in the victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers, averaging 16.3 points, 5.8 rebounds, 4.0 assists and 1.3 steals in 37.1 minutes per game while shooting .521/.400/.357.

Iguodala missed some time in 2015-16 with a sore hamstring and a sprained ankle, averaging 7.0 points, 4.0 rebounds, 3.4 assists and 1.1 steals in 26.6 minutes per game on .478/.351/.614 shooting in his 65 games.

He wasn’t as big a factor in the Finals rematch with Cleveland, averaging 9.1 points, 6.3 rebounds and 4.1 assists in 34.1 minutes per game, shooting .466/.304/3-for-9 and starting two of the seven games in the loss to the Cavs.

In three seasons with Golden State, Iguodala has averaged 8.0 points, 4.0 rebounds, 3.5 assists and 1.3 steals in 28.5 minutes per game, shooting .474/.351/.623.

He opted to leave college after averaging 12.9 points and 8.4 rebounds per game as a sophomore at Arizona.

The Philadelphia 76ers drafted the rangy swingman with the ninth overall pick in the 2004 NBA Draft and he blossomed.

He was a first team All-Rookie selection in 2004-05, earned All-Defensive honors in 2010-11 and was an All-Star in 2012 while with the Sixers.

Iguodala led the NBA in minutes per game in 2008-09 and was fourth in steals in 2006-07.

In August 2012, he was part of a mammoth four-team trade that wound up with him in Denver. The Los Angeles Lakers and Orlando Magic also participated in the swap.

Iguodala has one season remaining on the deal he signed in 2013.

He is 45th in NBA history with 1,472 steals.

Jun 10, 2016; Cleveland, OH, USA; Golden State Warriors center Andrew Bogut (12) blocks a shot by Cleveland Cavaliers center Tristan Thompson (13) during the third quarter in game four of the NBA Finals at Quicken Loans Arena. Mandatory Credit: Bob Donnan-USA TODAY Sports

Andrew Bogut

C, 2012-16

The Golden State Warriors landed former All-NBA center Andrew Bogut along with Stephen Jackson in a March 2012 trade with the Milwaukee Bucks in exchange for Monta Ellis, Kwame Brown and Ekpe Udoh.

Bogut was fragile, but a tenacious defender when healthy, earning All-Defensive honors in 2014-15 while helping the Warriors to an NBA title.

But he played in just four games in the 2015 NBA Finals, averaging 2.5 points, 6.0 rebounds and 1.3 blocks in 18.4 minutes per game, shooting 4-for-9/—/2-for-4 in the six-game win over the Cleveland Cavaliers.

Last season, Bogut appeared in 70 games–his highest total since 2007-08 in Milwaukee–and averaged 5.4 points, 7.0 rebounds, 2.3 assists and 1.6 blocks in 20.7 minutes per game on .627/1-for-1/.480 shooting.

A knee injury kept him out of the final two games of the NBA Finals rematch against the Cavaliers. In the five games he did appear, he averaged 3.2 points, 3.0 rebounds and 2.0 blocks in 12.0 minutes per game while shooting 8-for-17/0-for-1/—.

On July 7, 2016, Bogut was traded with a future second-round pick to the Dallas Mavericks for a conditional future second-round pick.

In four seasons in Golden State, Bogut averaged 6.3 points, 8.3 rebounds, 2.2 assists and 1.7 blocks in 23.7 minutes per game, shooting .581/2-for-2/.448.

An Australian native, Bogut was an All-American as a sophomore at Utah, averaging 20.4 points and 12.2 rebounds per game.

He was the first overall pick by the Bucks in the 2005 NBA Draft and was an All-Rookie selection in 2005-06 and an All-NBA pick in 2009-10, while leading the NBA in blocks in 2010-11.

Bogut has one year remaining on an extension he signed in 2013 and is Under contract with Golden State through 2016-17, he is 31st in NBA history with a field-goal percentage of .535 and 48th with an average of 1.6 blocks per game.

UNITED STATES – APRIL 02: Basketball: Golden State Warriors Baron Davis (5) in action, layup vs Dallas Mavericks, Dallas,TX 4/2/2008 (Photo by Greg Nelson/Sports Illustrated/Getty Images) (SetNumber: X80031 TK1 R1 F179)

Baron Davis

PG, 2005-08

The Golden State Warriors picked up former All-Star Baron Davis in a February 2005 trade with the New Orleans Hornets, giving up Dale Davis and Speedy Claxton.

Davis played a key role in the Warriors returning to the playoffs in 2007 after a 12-year absence, leading the NBA in steals in 2006-07.

He was third in the NBA in that category in 2007-08 before he left to sign with the Los Angeles Clippers as a free agent in July 2008.

In parts of four seasons in Golden State, Davis averaged 20.1 points, 8.1 assists, 4.4 rebounds and 2.0 steals in 36.9 minutes per game, shooting .418/.322/.731.

He was an All-American as a sophomore at UCLA, averaging 15.9 points per game, before entering the draft.

Davis was the third overall pick by the Charlotte Hornets in the 1999 NBA Draft and moved with the Hornets to New Orleans in 2002, leading the NBA in steals while earning All-NBA honors in 2003-04.

He was a two-time All-Star in New Orleans, as well.

In February 2011, he was traded to the Cleveland Cavaliers and signed with the New York Knicks in December 2011, five days after being waived by the Cavaliers.

He had not played since 2012 before appearing in six D-League games in 2015-16. He has not filed retirement papers.

Davis is 32nd in NBA history with 1,332 three-pointers, 34th with 6,025 assists, 38th with 1,530 steals, 24th with an average of 7.2 assists per game and 28th with an average of 1.8 steals per game.

Basketball: NBA Playoffs: Los Angeles Lakers Jerry West (44) in action vs San Francisco Warriors Rudy LaRusso (35) at The Forum.

Inglewood, CA 4/5/1968 – 4/10/1968

CREDIT: George Long (Photo by George Long /Sports Illustrated/Getty Images)

(Set Number: X13118 )

Rudy LaRusso

PF-SF, 1967-69

The Detroit Pistons’ loss turned into the San Francisco Warriors’ gain in August 1967, when the Warriors purchased the contract of unhappy former star Rudy LaRusso, who refused to report to Detroit after a January trade.

LaRusso bounced back well, earning two All-Star bids for the Warriors. He was also named All-Defensive in 1968-69 before retiring in June 1969.

In two seasons in San Francisco, LaRusso averaged 21.3 points, 8.9 rebounds and 2.2 assists in 36.4 minutes per game, shooting 42.2 percent from the floor and 79.2 percent at the line.

He averaged 18.9 points and 16.1 rebounds per game as a senior at Dartmouth and was a second-round pick by the Minneapolis Lakers in the 1959 NBA Draft.

LaRusso made two All-Star appearances after the team moved to Los Angeles in 1960.

LaRusso was traded to the Pistons as part of a three-team deal in January 1967, but refused to report.

LaRusso died July 9, 2004, in Los Angeles after a lengthy fight with Parkinson’s disease. He was 66.

Basketball: San Francisco Warriors Jeff Mullins (23) in action vs Cincinnai Royals. San Francisco, CA 11/1/1969 CREDIT: George Long (Photo by George Long /Sports Illustrated/Getty Images) (Set Number: X14515 )

Jeff Mullins

SG, 1966-76

Jeff Mullins was a little-used reserve who had been left exposed in the expansion draft before being acquired by the San Francisco Warriors in September 1966 along with Jim King and cash from the Chicago Bulls in exchange for Guy Rodgers.

He was a reserve with the Warriors as they made the 1967 NBA Finals, morphed into a three-time All-Star and earned a championship ring with Golden State in 1975.

Mullins was second in the NBA free-throw shooting in 1968-69, third in both 1969-70 and 1973-74 and fourth in 1970-71.

In the Finals against the Philadelphia 76ers in 1967, he averaged 14.0 points, 5.0 rebounds and 4.0 assists in 32.0 minutes per game, shooting 39.8 percent from the floor and 14-for-18 at the line in a six-game loss.

Mullins averaged 8.0 points, 3.3 rebounds, 1.8 assists and 1.0 steals in 19.3 minutes per game, shooting 55.2 percent from the floor and going 0-for-2 at the line in a four-game sweep of the Washington Bullets in the 1975 NBA Finals.

He remained with the Warriors until retiring in June 1976.

In 10 seasons with San Francisco and Golden State, Mullins averaged 17.5 points, 4.5 rebounds and 4.1 assists in 32.8 minutes per game, shooting 46.6 percent from the field and 81.8 percent at the foul line.

An All-American as a senior at Duke, he averaged 24.2 points and 8.9 rebounds per game as he led the Blue Devils to the Final Four.

Mullins was the fifth overall pick by the St. Louis Hawks in the 1964 NBA Draft and was chosen by Chicago in the expansion draft in May 1966.

He was later the head coach and athletic director at UNC Charlotte from 1985-96, going 182-142 in 11 seasons and taking the 49ers to three NCAA tournaments.

Jan 17, 2015; Houston, TX, USA; Golden State Warriors forward David Lee (10) drives the ball to the basket during the third quarter as Houston Rockets guard Corey Brewer (33) defends at Toyota Center. Mandatory Credit: Troy Taormina-USA TODAY Sports

David Lee

PF, 2010-15

David Lee had become an unlikely All-Star just before hitting free agency.

After agreeing to a deal with the Golden State Warriors, Lee was acquired in a sign-and-trade from the New York Knicks in exchange for Ronny Turiaf, Anthony Randolph, Kelenna Azubuike and second-round picks in 2012 and 2013.

Lee was an All-Star for the Warriors in 2013 and earned All-NBA honors in 2012-13, finishing fifth in the NBA in rebounding that season.

A hamstring injury hampered Lee in 2014 and he became a reserve for the club.

He played in four games in the 2015 NBA Finals, averaging 5.5 points, 2.5 rebounds and 1.5 assists in 9.7 minutes per game, shooting 8-for-15/—/6-for-11 as the Warriors beat the Cleveland Cavaliers in six games.

He was traded to the Boston Celtics in July 2015 in exchange for Gerald Wallace and Chris Babb.

In five seasons in Golden State, Lee averaged 16.7 points, 9.3 rebounds and 2.8 assists in 33.2 minutes per game, shooting .513/1-for-15/.776. He does not appear on any of the franchise’s all-time leaderboards.

As a senior at Florida, he averaged 13.6 points and 9.0 rebounds per game and was 30th overall pick by the Knicks in the 2005 NBA Draft.

Lee was named an All-Star for New York in 2010.

Waived by the Celtics on Feb. 19, 2016, Lee signed with the Dallas Mavericks three days later. For the 2015-16 season, he averaged 7.8 points and 5.5 rebounds in 16.4 points per game, shooting .531/0-for-1/.763 in 55 games.

He signed a two-year, $3.2 million deal with the San Antonio Spurs on Aug. 2, 2016, with the second year in 2017-18 being a player option.

Lee is 34th in NBA history with a field-goal percentage of .533.

MILWAUKEE, WI – CIRCA 1975: Phil Smith #20 of the Golden State Warriors drives on Junior Bridgeman #2 of the Milwaukee Bucks during an NBA basketball game circa 1975 at the MECCA Arena in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. Smith played for the Warriors from 1974-80. (Photo by Focus on Sport/Getty Images) *** Local Caption *** Phil Smith; Junior Bridgeman

Phil Smith

SG, 1974-80

Phil Smith was a San Francisco native who stayed home to play collegiately at the University of San Francisco, averaging almost 21 points and more than five rebounds per game as a senior.

The Golden State Warriors noticed and took Smith in the second round, 29th overall, of the 1974 NBA Draft.

He was a reserve on their 1975 championship team, but went on to become a two-time All-Star and was an All-NBA and All-Defensive selection in 1975-76. He was also fifth in the NBA in minutes per game in 1978-79.

In the 1975 NBA Finals, Smith averaged 10.8 points, 3.0 rebounds, 2.5 assists and 1.3 blocks in 24.0 minutes per game, shooting 41 percent from the floor and 11-for-18 at the line in the Warriors’ four-game sweep of the Washington Bullets.

Smith was traded in August 1980 along with a 1984 first-round pick to the San Diego Clippers in exchange for World B. Free.

In six seasons in Golden State, Smith averaged 17.1 points, 3.9 assists, 3.5 rebounds and 1.3 steals in 31.4 minutes per game, shooting .480/.318/.790.

Smith was traded to the Seattle SuperSonics in February 1982 and retired after he was waived in September 1983.

He died July 29, 2002, from complications due to bone marrow cancer, something he battled over the final five years of his life, at the age of 50.

Russler. Philly’s Tom Gola (15) tries neat layup but that man Bill Russell (rear) looms up to block shot. (Photo by Charles Hoff/NY Daily News via Getty Images)

Tom Gola

SG, 1955-56, 1957-62

Tom Gola was a three-time All-American at La Salle who had led them to an unlikely national title as a junior in 1954.

The Philadelphia Warriors made sure he wasn’t going anywhere in the 1955 NBA Draft, using their territorial selection to take the Philly native.

His career kicked into high gear after he returned from a one-year stint in the U.S. Army, earning three All-Star bids and an All-NBA selection in 1957-58.

Gola was fourth in the NBA in assists in 1955-56 and 1967-68 and finished fifth in 1959-60.

At the end of his rookie year, he averaged 13.8 points, 10.0 rebounds and 6.0 assists, shooting 38.5 percent from the floor and 76 percent at the line as the Warriors topped the Fort Wayne Pistons in five games to win the 1956 NBA championship.

In December 1962, after the Warriors had moved to San Francisco, he was traded to the New York Knicks in exchange for Kenny Sears and Willie Naulls.

In parts of seven seasons in Philadelphia and San Francisco, Gola averaged 13.6 points, 9.9 rebounds and 4.9 assists in 37.2 minutes per game, shooting 42.5 percent from the floor and 76.3 percent at the line.

A two-time All-Star with the Knicks, Gola retired in June 1966.

He returned to La Salle for two seasons as head coach, going 37-13 from 1968-70.

Inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame in 1976, Gola died Jan. 26, 2014, in Philadelphia at the age of 81.

Apr 9, 2016; Memphis, TN, USA; Golden State Warriors guard Klay Thompson (11) dribbles the ball as Memphis Grizzlies guard Lance Stephenson (1) defends in the first quarter at FedExForum. Mandatory Credit: Nelson Chenault-USA TODAY Sports

Klay Thompson

SG, 2011-16

Klay Thompson put up averages of almost 22 points and more than five rebounds per game as a junior at Washington State, opting to turn pro.

The Golden State Warriors grabbed the shooting guard with the 11th overall pick in the 2011 NBA Draft.

They haven’t regretted the pick. He was an All-Rookie selection in 2011-12 and is a two-time All-Star and All-NBA selection.

Thompson was fourth in the NBA in three-point shooting in 2014-15 and was second in three-pointers in 2013-14 and 2014-15 and third in 2012-13.

Thompson added his second All-Star berth and All-NBA selection to his resume in 2015-16, finishing second in the NBA in three-pointers.

In 80 games, he averaged 22.1 points, 3.8 rebounds and 2.1 assists in 33.3 minutes per game on .470/.425/.873 shooting.

He averaged 15.8 points, 4.3 rebounds, 1.7 assists and a block in 37.9 minutes per game in the 2015 NBA Finals, shooting .409/.300/11-for-12 in the Warriors’ six-game victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers.

In a seven-game loss in an NBA Finals rematch with the Cavaliers in 2016, Thompson put up 19.6 points, 3.0 rebounds and 1.0 steals in 35.3 minutes per game while shooting .427/.350/.786.

In five seasons in Golden State, Thompson is averaging 18.4 points, 3.3 rebounds and 2.3 assists in 32.5 minutes per game, shooting .450/.420/.853.

Thompson still has three years remaining on an extension signed in October 2014. He is 12th in NBA history with a three-point percentage of .420.

OAKLAND, CA – CIRCA 1975: Jamaal Wilkes #41 of the Golden State Warriors drives to the basket against the Seattle Super Sonics during an NBA basketball game circa 1975 at the Oakland-Alameda Coliseum in Oakland, California. Wilkes played for the Warriors from 1974-77. (Photo by Focus on Sport/Getty Images) *** Local Caption *** Jamaal Wilkes

Jamaal Wilkes

SF-PF, 1974-77

A two-time All-American at UCLA, Jamaal Wilkes had averaged nearly 17 points and seven rebounds per game as a senior and was a two-time national champion.

He was selected 11th overall by the Golden State Warriors in the 1974 NBA Draft.

Wilkes rose to the head of the class, earning Rookie of the Year honors in 1974-75. He was an All-Star in 1976 and a two-time All-Defensive selection for the Warriors, as well.

He averaged 11.5 points, 9.8 rebounds and 1.8 steals in 26.8 minutes per game in the 1975 NBA Finals, shooting 32.1 percent from the floor and 10-for-12 at the line in a four-game sweep of the Washington Bullets.

Wilkes signed with the Los Angeles Lakers in July 1977 as a veteran free agent, with the Warriors receiving a 1978 first-round pick and cash as compensation.

In three seasons in Golden State, Wilkes averaged 16.5 points, 8.2 rebounds, 2.3 assists and 1.4 steals in 32.5 minutes per game, shooting 46.1 percent from the floor and 77.1 percent at the line.

With the Lakers, he was a two-time All-Star and was part of two NBA title clubs before being waived in August 1985.

He signed with the Los Angeles Clippers in September 1985 and retired in December of that year.

Wilkes was inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame in 2012.

March 1, 2016; Oakland, CA, USA; Golden State Warriors forward Draymond Green (23) shoots the basketball against Atlanta Hawks forward Paul Millsap (4, left) and center Al Horford (15) during the second quarter at Oracle Arena. Mandatory Credit: Kyle Terada-USA TODAY Sports

Draymond Green

SF-PF, 2012-16

Draymond Green was an All-American as a senior at Michigan State, earning praise as one of the top all-around players in the nation as he averaged 16.2 points and 10.6 rebounds per game.

But he fell into the dreaded “tweener” category and his draft stock plummeted to the point he was still on the board before the Golden State Warriors selected him in the second round, 35th overall, of the 2012 NBA Draft.

That pick has reaped rewards far beyond its initial value.

Green was an All-Defensive pick in 2014-15, when he moved into the starting lineup full-time at the power forward spot and helped the Warriors to an NBA championship.

In the NBA Finals against the Cleveland Cavaliers, Green put up 13.0 points, 8.3 rebounds, 5.0 assists, 2.2 steals and 1.2 blocks in 37.0 minutes per game on .381/5-for-19/.735 shooting.

He was just getting started.

Green’s breakout campaign was followed by an even bigger emergence in 2015-16, when he earned his first All-NBA and All-Star nods while repeating as an All-Defensive selection.

He averaged 14.0 points, 9.5 rebounds, 7.4 assists, 1.5 steals and 1.4 blocks in 34.7 minutes per game while shooting .390/.388/.696 in the 81 games in which he started.

Green missed Game 5 of the NBA Finals rematch with the Cavaliers because of a suspension.

In the six games he played, he was good for 16.5 points, 10.3 rebounds, 6.3 assists, 1.7 steals and 1.0 blocks in 40.0 minutes per game on .486/.406/.783 shooting, but the Warriors fell in seven games.

In four seasons with Golden State, Green has averaged 8.7 points, 6.5 rebounds, 3.4 assists, 1.2 steals and 1.0 blocks in 25.4 minutes per game, shooting .440/.342/.690.

He has four years remaining on the five-year, $82 million free agent deal he signed in July 2015.

Basketball: NBA Playoffs: Golden State Warriors Tim Hardaway (10) in action vs Seattle SuperSonics at Oakland-Alameda County Coliseum Arena. Game 1.

Oakland, CA 4/23/1992

CREDIT: John W. McDonough (Photo by John W. McDonough /Sports Illustrated/Getty Images)

(Set Number: X42794 )

Tim Hardaway

PG, 1989-96

Tim Hardaway starred outside of the spotlight at UTEP, averaging 22 points and more than five assists per game as a senior.

Despite concerns about his size, he was selected 14th overall by the Golden State Warriors in the 1989 NBA Draft.

He was an All-Rookie selection in 1989-90 and went on to be named a three-time All-Star and two-time All-NBA selection for the Warriors, bouncing back from missing the entire 1993-94 season with a knee injury.

Hardaway was second in the NBA in assists in 1992-93, third in 1991-92 and 1994-95 and fifth in 1990-91, also placing fourth in steals and minutes per game in 1990-91 and second in minutes per game in 1991-92.

In February 1996, he was traded with Chris Gatling to the Miami Heat in exchange for Kevin Willis and Bimbo Coles.

In parts of six seasons in Golden State, Hardaway averaged 19.8 points, 9.3 assists, 3.6 rebounds and 1.9 steals in 37.0 minutes per game, shooting .455/.355/.768.

Hardaway was a two-time All-Star and three-time All-NBA selection with the Heat before he was traded to the Dallas Mavericks in August 2001.

In February 2002, he was dealt to the Denver Nuggets and was waived in June 2002.

He returned to the NBA with the Indiana Pacers in March 2003 and retired at the end of the 2002-03 season.

An assistant coach with the Detroit Pistons since 2014, Hardaway is 23rd in NBA history with 1,542 three-pointers, 15th with 7,095 assists, 49th with 1,428 steals and 13th with an average of 8.2 assists per game.

Basketball: Golden State Warriors Chris Mullin (17) in action vs Chicago Bulls. Portland, OR 11/22/1991 CREDIT: Peter Read Miller (Photo by Peter Read Miller /Sports Illustrated/Getty Images) (Set Number: X42099 )

Chris Mullin

SF-SG, 1985-97, 2000-01

Chris Mullin won the Wooden Award as a senior at St. John’s, averaging almost 20 points and five rebounds and more than four assists a game while helping the Redmen to the Final Four.

The Golden State Warriors selected the swingman seventh overall in the 1985 NBA Draft.

After some early troubles with alcoholism, Mullin developed into a five-time All-Star and a four-time All-NBA selection for the Warriors and led the league in minutes per game in 1990-91 and 1991-92.

He was fourth in scoring in 1991-92 and fifth in both 1988-89 and 1992-93, finished second in three-point shooting in 1992-93, fifth in field-goal percentage in 1996-97 and second in free-throw shooting in 1985-86 while placing fifth in 1988-89.

In August 1997, he was traded to the Indiana Pacers in exchange for Erick Dampier and Duane Ferrell.

Mullin returned to the Warriors as a free agent in September 2000, retiring at the end of the 2000-01 season.

In 13 seasons in Golden State, Mullin averaged 20.1 points, 4.4 rebounds, 3.9 assists and 1.7 steals in 35 minutes per game, shooting .513/.366/.862.

Mullin was general manager of the Warriors from 2004-09 and was hired as head coach at St. John’s in March 2015, where he is 8-24 through one season.

Inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame in 2011, he is 38th in NBA history with 1,530 steals and 30th with a free-throw percentage of .866.

Basketball: NBA Playoffs: Golden State Warriors Nate Thurmond (42) in action, rebounding vs Milwaukee Bucks at Milwaukee Arena. Game 1.

Milwaukee, WI 3/28/1972

CREDIT: Heinz Kluetmeier (Photo by Heinz Kluetmeier /Sports Illustrated/Getty Images)

(Set Number: X16670 )

Nate Thurmond

C-PF, 1963-74

Nate Thurmond was a beast at Bowling Green, averaging almost 18 points and 17 rebounds per game over his three varsity seasons.

The San Francisco Warriors selected Thurmond third overall in the 1963 NBA Draft.

He was an All-Rookie selection in 1963-64, but his career shot into orbit when he moved from power forward back to his natural center spot in his third season.

Thurmond was a seven-time All-Star and a five-time All-Defensive selection for the Warriors and finished second in the MVP voting in 1966-67.

He finished in the top five in rebounding six times, including three second-place finishes, and was in the top five in minutes per game four times, finishing second twice.

Battling Wilt Chamberlain in the 1967 NBA Finals, Thurmond averaged 14.2 points, 26.7 rebounds and 3.3 assists per game, shooting 34.3 percent from the floor and 54.8 percent at the line in a six-game loss to the Philadelphia 76ers.

In September 1974, Thurmond was traded to the Chicago Bulls in exchange for Clifford Ray and a first-round pick in 1975.

In 11 seasons in San Francisco and Golden State, Thurmond averaged 17.4 points, 16.9 rebounds, 2.9 blocks and 2.7 assists in 40.6 minutes per game, shooting 42.5 percent from the floor and 67.6 percent at the line.

He was traded to the Cleveland Cavaliers in November 1975 and retired in September 1977.

Inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame in 1985, he is 10th in NBA history with 14,464 rebounds, 24th with an average of 37.2 minutes per game and fifth with an average of 15.0 rebounds per game.

Thurmond died July 16, 2016, at the age of 74 following a bout with leukemia.

UNITED STATES – NOVEMBER 03: Basketball: Philadelphia Warriors Neil Johnston (6) in action, taking shot vs New York Knicks Ray Felix (19), New York, NY 11/3/1957 (Photo by Hy Peskin/Sports Illustrated/Getty Images) (SetNumber: X4854)

Neil Johnston

C, 1951-59

Neil Johnston was a 6-foot-8 right-handed pitcher in the Philadelphia Phillies’ organization who didn’t make the grade in three seasons and decided to fall back on professional basketball, since he had played a couple of years at Ohio State.

The Philadelphia Warriors signed Johnston in June 1951, three years after his final collegiate season.

After a year as a reserve, Johnston became the starting center for the Warriors and went on to become a six-time All-Star and a five-time All-NBA selection, leading the NBA in scoring three straight seasons (1952-53 through 1954-55) and in rebounding in 1954-55.

He was the league’s top field-goal percentage man in 1952-53, 1955-56 and 1956-57, as well, and topped the NBA in minutes per game in 1952-53 and 1953-54.

In the 1956 NBA Finals, Johnston averaged 13.6 points, 11.0 rebounds and 3.8 assists per game, shooting 33.8 percent from the floor and 61.1 percent at the line as the Warriors beat the Fort Wayne Pistons in five games.

A severe knee injury forced him to retire at the end of the 1958-59 season.

In eight seasons in Philadelphia, Johnston averaged 19.4 points, 11.3 rebounds and 2.5 assists in 35.5 minutes per game, shooting 44.4 percent from the floor and 76.8 percent at the line.

Johnston later coached the Warriors to a 95-59 record in the regular season, going 4-8 in the playoffs, from 1959-61, and was an assistant coach with the Portland Trail Blazers from 1972-74.

He died Sept. 28, 1978, in Irving, Texas, reportedly from a heart attack while playing in a pickup game. He was just 49 years old.

Inducted posthumously into the Basketball Hall of Fame in 1990, Johnston is 22nd in NBA history with an average of 11.3 rebounds per game.

(Original Caption) Paul Arizin (11) of the Philadelphia Warriors tries for a basket under the basket in the first half of the game with the Knicks at the Garden. Ken Sears (12) of the Knicks makes an attempt to stop his throw.

Paul Arizin

SF, 1950-52, 1954-62

There are stories about players lightly recruited out of high school that went on to become stars at the collegiate and pro levels. Paul Arizin did that one better, becoming a star at the collegiate and pro levels after not playing high school basketball at all.

Spotted in a Catholic Youth Organization game in Philadelphia, Arizin wound up making the team at Villanova … and then some. He was an All-American as a senior, averaging more than 25 points per game, and was the Philadelphia Warriors’ territorial selection in the 1950 NBA Draft.

Arizin was a 10-time All-Star in 12 years with the Warriors—missing only in the two seasons he was serving in the U.S. Marine Corps. He was also a four-time All-NBA selection and was second in the NBA MVP voting in 1955-56, third in 1956-57 and fifth in 1958-59.

He was a two-time NBA scoring champion (1951-52 and 1956-57) and led the league in minutes per game in 1951-52 and 1954-55.

Six times he finished in the top five in scoring, he led the league in field-goal percentage in 1951-52, was fourth in free-throw shooting in 1956-57 and was the MVP of the 1952 All-Star Game.

Arizin averaged 27.6 points, 8.0 rebounds and 2.8 assists per game, shooting 42.6 percent from the floor and 87.5 percent at the line while leading the Warriors to a five-game victory over the Fort Wayne Pistons in the 1956 NBA Finals.

He retired after the 1961-62 season rather than follow the team to San Francisco.

In 10 seasons in Philadelphia, Arizin averaged 22.8 points, 8.6 rebounds and 2.3 assists in 38.4 minutes per game, shooting 42.1 percent from the floor and 81 percent at the line.

Arizin is 12th in NBA history with an average of 38.4 minutes per game and 23rd with an average of 22.8 points per game.

He was inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame in 1978. He died Dec. 12, 2006, in Springfield, Pa., at the age of 78.

Basketball: NBA Playoffs: Golden State Warriors Rick Barry (24) in action, pass to Jeff Mullins (23) vs Milwaukee Bucks Oscar Robertson (1) at Oakland-Alameda County Coliseum Arena. Game 6.

Oakland, CA 4/13/1973

CREDIT: George Long (Photo by George Long /Sports Illustrated/Getty Images)

(Set Number: X17597 )

Rick Barry

SF, 1965-67, 1972-78

Rick Barry had a complicated relationship with the San Francisco and Golden State Warriors, leaving the team to jump to the ABA after two seasons and signing a future contract two years after leaving for the ABA.

An All-American at Miami, averaging more than 37 points and 18 rebounds a game as a senior, Barry was taken second overall by the Warriors in the 1965 NBA Draft and blossomed quickly.

He was the NBA Rookie of the Year in 1965-66 and was a two-time All-Star and two-time All-NBA selection, leading the NBA in scoring in 1966-67 while taking the Warriors to the NBA Finals. He finished fifth in the MVP voting that season.

Barry averaged 40.8 points, 8.8 rebounds and 3.3 assists in 43.3 minutes per game, shooting 40 percent from the floor and 79.2 percent at the line in a six-game loss to the Philadelphia 76ers in the 1967 NBA Finals.

But in July 1967, Barry signed with the ABA’s Oakland Oaks. The Warriors filed suit in a California court and got an injunction that prevented Barry from playing for Oakland until 1968.

He signed a future contract with the Warriors in August 1969 that would take effect at the end of his ABA deal in 1972.

While in the ABA, he was a four-time All-Star and four-time All-ABA performer. He wandered with the Oaks franchise to Washington in 1969 and Virginia in 1970 before he was traded to the New York Nets.

Back with the Warriors, now known as Golden State, in 1972, Barry picked up where he left off, earning six more All-Star nods and four All-NBA berths, finishing fourth in the MVP voting in 1974-75 and 1975-76.

Barry led the NBA in free-throw shooting four times with Golden State, was second in the league in scoring in 1974-75 and fifth in 1975-76, also finished fifth in assists in 1975-76 and led the league in steals in 1974-75.

He averaged 29.5 points, five assists, four rebounds and 3.5 steals in 43 minutes per game, shooting 44.4 percent from the floor and 93.8 percent at the line while leading Golden State to a four-game sweep of the Washington Bullets in the 1975 NBA Finals, earning Finals MVP honors on the way.

He left a second time in June 1978 to sign as a veteran free agent with the Houston Rockets, with the Warriors receiving John Lucas and cash as compensation.

In eight seasons with San Francisco and Golden State, Barry averaged 25.6 points, 7.3 rebounds, 5.1 assists and 2.3 steals in 38.1 minutes per game, shooting 44.9 percent from the floor and 89.6 percent at the line.

He led the NBA in free-throw shooting twice more with the Rockets before retiring in September 1980.

Inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame in 1987, Barry is fourth in NBA history with a free-throw percentage of .900, 39th with an average of 36.3 minutes per game and 21st with an average of 23.2 points per game.

He was the ABA’s all-time leader with an .880 free-throw percentage and an average of 30.5 points per game.

Jun 16, 2016; Cleveland, OH, USA; Golden State Warriors guard Stephen Curry (30) shoots the ball against Cleveland Cavaliers forward Richard Jefferson (24) during the first quarter in game six of the NBA Finals at Quicken Loans Arena. Mandatory Credit: Bob Donnan-USA TODAY Sports

Stephen Curry

PG, 2009-16

Stephen Curry was a two-time All-America at Davidson, averaging almost 29 points and six assists as a junior before opting for the pros.

The Golden State Warriors took the point guard with the seventh overall pick in the 2009 NBA Draft.

He was an All-Rookie selection in 2009-10 and has steadily improved, shaking off ankle troubles early in his career, to earn back-to-back NBA MVP honors in 2014-15 and 2015-16.

Curry is also a three-time All-Star and three-time All-NBA selection who has led the league in three-pointers four straight seasons (2012-13 through 2014-15) and has been the best free-throw shooter three times.

While pacing the Warriors to the NBA title in 2015, Curry averaged 26.0 points, 6.3 assists, 5.2 rebounds and 1.8 steals in 42.5 minutes per game, shooting .443/.385/.885 in a six-game victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers in the NBA Finals.

What he did during the 2015-16 season defied logic.

Curry became the league’s first unanimous MVP, averaging 30.1 points, 6.7 assists, 5.4 rebounds and 2.1 steals in 34.2 minutes per game on .504/.454/.908 shooting, joining the rare 50-40-90 club.

He led the league in scoring (his 34.2 minutes per game the lowest ever for a scoring champ), steals, free-throw shooting and shattered his own NBA record for three-pointers in a season.

In a seven-game loss to the Cavaliers in the NBA Finals, he was limited to 22.6 points, 4.9 rebounds and 3.7 assists in 35.1 minutes per game on .403/.400/.929 shooting.

In seven seasons in Golden State, Curry is averaging 22.4 points, 6.9 assists, 4.3 rebounds and 1.8 steals in 34.9 minutes per game, shooting .477/.444/.902.

He is 19th in NBA history with 1,593 three-pointers, second with a .444 three-point percentage, third with a .902 free-throw percentage, 25th with an average of 22.4 points per game, 29th with an average of 6.9 assists per game and 37th with an average of 1.8 steals per game.

Curry has one year remaining on a four-year, $44 million extension he signed in October 2012.

Basketball: Aerial view of Philadelphia Warriors Wilt Chamberlain (13) in action vs Los Angeles Lakers Ray Felix (14). View of Lakers Hot Rod Hundley (33) and Elgin Baylor (22). Philadelphia, PA 10/20/1961 CREDIT: John G. Zimmerman (Photo by John G. Zimmerman /Sports Illustrated/Getty Images) (Set Number: X8140 TK3 )

Wilt Chamberlain

C, 1959-65

Philadelphia native Wilt Chamberlain was a two-time All-American at Kansas before leaving school and playing a year with the Harlem Globetrotters before becoming eligible to be drafted.

The Philadelphia Warriors used their territorial selection in the 1959 NBA Draft to grab Chamberlain and were handsomely rewarded.

Chamberlain was the first player in NBA history to be named Rookie of the Year and MVP in the same season, turning the trick in 1959-60.

He was a six-time All-Star and five-time All-NBA selection with the Warriors, finishing second in the MVP voting in 1961-62 and 1963-64 and fourth in 1960-61.

He led the NBA in scoring every season he was with the team to go with four rebounding titles, leading the league in minutes per game five times and twice topping the circuit in field-goal percentage.

Chamberlain led the Warriors, in their second season in San Francisco, to the NBA Finals in 1964, averaging 29.2 points, 27.6 rebounds and 2.4 assists in 46 minutes per game, shooting 51.7 percent from the floor and 41.5 percent at the line in a five-game loss to the Boston Celtics.

He was traded to the Philadelphia 76ers in January 1965 in exchange for Connie Dierking, Lee Shaffer, Paul Neumann and cash.

In parts of six seasons in Philadelphia and San Francisco, Chamberlain averaged 41.5 points, 25.1 rebounds and 3.0 assists in 47.2 minutes per game, shooting 50.6 percent from the floor and 55.5 percent at the line.

Chamberlain was a three-time MVP, three-time All-Star and four-time All-NBA selection with the 76ers, helping them to an NBA title in 1967, before being traded to the Los Angeles Lakers in July 1968.

With Los Angeles, Chamberlain was Finals MVP in 1972, a four-time All-Star, an All-NBA selection in 1971-72 and a two-time All-Defensive pick.

He signed with the ABA’s San Diego Conquistadors in September 1973, but was barred by court order from playing for the team. After coaching the Q’s to a 37-47 record, he retired in 1974.

Chamberlain was inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame in 1979.

The NBA’s all-time leader with 23,924 rebounds and averages of 45.8 minutes and 22.9 rebounds per game, he is also seventh in league history with 47,859 minutes played, fifth with 31,419 points, 26th with a field-goal percentage of .540.

He died from heart-related problems in Bel Air, Calif., on Oct. 12, 1999, at the age of 63.
